Évaluation publiée le 28 juin 2018
I love puzzle games. Let me rephrase that. I love puzzles games where the puzzles have some kind of logical solution that the developers don't try to hide for the sake of being clever. That's what happened to Lake Ridden.

Pros
Graphics are very well done
Open world feel
Several puzzles to solve
Well optimized

♥♥♥♥
Many of the puzzles are nonsensical
Dreary atmosphere
Some of the clues are out right lies
Repetitive puzzles
Very short
Too much walking back and forth

I knew there was going to be a problem with this game right from the start. Your first puzzle is to find the code to the gate. Well, much easier said than done. The game forces you to make assumptions, which may or may not be right. Let's use the gate code answer. There's a note on the gate reminding the owner to change the code to the year his brother disappeared. In his journal (shocker, a journal) he mentions that it had been 50 years and the journal entry is dated 1985. So the code is 1935, right? Wrong. The developer said that you have to assume he never made it back but you don't find that out until you open the gate and continue on. (GROAN)

That was just one example. Unfortunately, it wasn't an isolated incident. Many of the solutions to the puzzles are so convoluted, that they don't make any kind of logical sense. There are some clues that out right lie to you forcing you to look up the answer on YouTube and wonder how in the hell did they get that answer. However, not all of the puzzles are like that. There are a some that are very logical and well thought out but they are in the minority.

One of the reasons I bought this game is because most of the preview video shows a wonderful, beautiful world full of color. Don't be fooled. Most of this game takes place in a dark, which transcends into a day time sequence but that's short lived. For the last half of this game, you'll be walking back and fourth through a foggy and rainy night. Very dismal indeed.

At the time of this review, Lake Ridden was selling for $19.99. This game had me more frustrated then entertained. I'd stay away from it.

Évaluation publiée le 2 juillet 2020
If you liked the review and interested in completion and perfection time of games with additional useful information (for example: how difficult to get all achievements, is MP or DLC required and so on) or interested in reviews like this, then please follow my Average Achievement Hunter curator.

Lake Ridden is a story-driven, first-person puzzle game and by today’s standard it could be called as a walking simulator too.

You play as a young girl who is looking for her sister in a forest. This forest hides a long abandoned estate and a village. While the setting might promise a horror game, this isn’t one. Lake Ridden focuses on puzzles and on a story with full background information scattered all around the area. Notes, letters, articles.

The game offers a wide variety of puzzles. Some are easy, some are hard. If you like to play games where you need to use your brain then you shouldn’t have real difficulty to finish Lake Ridden but even you can find some challenging ones.

Conclusion

Lake Ridden is an ok puzzle game with an interesting story. You can find better games in the same genre, still, could offer a nice entertainment for 5-8 hours. I would probably never have bought this game at full price, but I got it cheaper. I feel so, that it was worth the price I paid for it.

Story: 7/10
Voice Acting: 8/10
Replay value: 1/10
Atmosphere: 7/10
Visuals: 7/10
Gameplay mechanics: 7/10
Music/Sound effects: 7/10
Game difficulty: 3/10

Hey, I am an achievement hunter!
Perfection time: ~5-8h. 1 playthrough enough but there are many optional puzzle boxes so there are missable achievements. Don’t be afraid if you missed anything on your first playthrough, via chapter select you can return easily to any missed ones.

Évaluation publiée le 23 octobre 2021
Lake Ridden is a first person Myst like puzzle game with lots of walking. It took me over 14hrs, but most people take around 8-10 hours play, so good value. Lake Ridden is a classic example of a game that could have been exceptional, but was failed by its confusing plot.
You play as Marie, a 13yr old girl on a camping trip with your younger sister and friends. You have an argument and she vanishes into the wilderness. The story is you trying to find her and what you discover along the way. The canvas of this game is large as you stumble upon an abandoned estate, with a mansion, school, servant's quarter, wharf and lake. There is no fast travel, but you gain a map further into the game.
The developers nailed the atmosphere perfectly. It was deliciously spooky with appropriate music to enhance the gloominess. The graphics are stunning and really hold up the game. This is not a horror game and there were no jump scares. If this cowardy custard could play this, anyone can!!!
Sadly, the game was let down by the convoluted and confusing story about the previous occupant of the estate and his servants. The story unfolds by finding pieces of paper scattered around the place as well as journals, puzzle and music boxes. There are 9 puzzle boxes which increase in difficulty as the game progresses. Some are very well hidden. The music boxes were very easy to crack as they are really memory tests.
To enter a new area, most gates or doors have a circular mosaic puzzle. These can be tricky because the background is very dark. The repetitiveness of the puzzles grated after a while.
To activate the lift, there is a musical puzzle and you are required to state whether the note is high, low or medium. As I'm hearing impaired, I had to look up the answer. Just a heads up for deaf people.
The devs got lazy with the interior of the mansion and quarters. The drawers and cupboards held the same contents everywhere and it was tedious going through them all to find a piece of paper. The attic was where the game really dragged as some of the puzzles were illogical. Thank goodness for a walkthrough!
In the end, I felt the game was being padded out by having to walk from one end of the map to the other multiple times. The story was silly, I personally thought, and I was never really engaged by it. If it wasn't for the beautiful graphics, I would have binned the game a long time ago!
This game would have been a stunning walking simulator without the confusing story and some of the puzzles could have broken up the walking. Great potential here, but it was sadly squandered.
Buy on sale. Recommend as it is not a bad game, just a bit too long. 7/10

Évaluation publiée le 15 avril 2021
*Lake Ridden* - Die Erwartungen wurden nicht erfüllt!

Lake Ridden ist ein First-Person-Walking-Simmulator, bei dem wir uns auf die Suche nach unserer vermissten Schwester machen. Während eines Streits bei einem Camping-Wochenende in der Wildnis von Maine ist sie einfach in den Wald gelaufen und es fehlt seither jede Spur von ihr.

Am Anfang wandern wir deshalb durch einen fast schon ein wenig mystischen Wald mit toller Atmosphäre. Dort stoßen wir immer wieder auf kleine Puzzle-Einlagen, die recht gelungen in die Geschichte integriert sind und Spaß machen. Als kleine Orientierungshilfe in der Dunkelheit können wir Laternen und Kerzen auf unserem Weg entzünden. So lässt sich immer gut nachvollziehen, welche Wege wir bereits untersucht haben. Eine schöne Idee.

Im weiteren Verlauf der Geschichte entdecken wir dann ein altes Anwesen, das voller Geheimnisse steckt und begeben uns damit auf eine Art Zeitreise in die Vergangenheit der ehemaligen Bewohner dort. Ab hier wird die Geschichte zunehmend verworrener und nur noch sehr schwer bis gar nicht mehr nachvollziehbar. Dies gilt auch für die Puzzles. Einzelne, durchaus gelungene Rätsel gehen in einer Flut unlogischer Rätsel unter. Zudem wiederholen sich Rätsel häufig. So auch die Vorgehensweise bei den insgesamt 9 Rätselboxen, die im Rahmen eines integrierten Sammelmodus gefunden und geöffnet werden wollen.

Zudem wird die Erkundung mehr und mehr zur Fleiß- und Laufarbeit. Mühsam klappern wir das riesige Gelände mehrfach ab. Da weder die Steuerung mit der Maus noch die Steuerung mit Controller wirklich ausgereift erscheint, wird dies zunehmend unspaßiger und und unglaublich langweilig. Ebenso die Tatsache, dass Notizen, die vielleicht etwas Licht ins Dunkel der Geschichte bringen könnten, wahllos in irgendwelchen Schubladen und Fächern versteckt liegen. Dies zwingt uns dazu, hunderte von Schubladen aufzumachen, nur um dann festzustellen, dass wir ein weiteres sinnfreies Geschreibsel gefunden haben.

Was so atmosphärisch dicht und schön begonnen hatte, entwickelte sich innerhalb kürzester Zeit zum reinsten Alptraum, der dazu noch unnötig in die Länge gezogen wurde. Ich war einfach nur noch genervt. Das Spiel hat weder als Walking-Simmulator noch als Puzzle-Spiel überzeugt und von der Geschichte will ich erst gar nicht reden. Ich kann nur davon abraten, hierfür Zeit und Geld zu verschwenden!

Évaluation publiée le 26 juin 2021
For more puzzle game reviews, news and everything puzzle-related, follow Puzzle Lovers and check out our Steam group.

I had reservations about lake ridden due to its suboptimal save system discussed on the forum, but it turned out to be tolerable and the overall experience just about recommendable on deep sale. there's a lot to unpack though.

the premise is that you, marie, are looking for your sister in what I thought would be an abandoned camp site in a forest. it turned out to be a big abandoned estate on a big lake with a big house and a big garden and a big courtyard. and since we're not talking about food or other stuff benefiting from size, big is one of the issues.

the game claims not to be a walking simulator, but there's an awful lot of largely pointless walking, often from one end of the map to the other, then back, while opening drawers containing mostly nothing. you can also light a bunch of candles, lanterns and such because most of the game is dark as ♥♥♥♥. you'll eventually find a map to ease with navigation, but no fast travel, and so no reason not to sprint everywhere.

you'll piece together the story, including other missing people and the former residents of the estate, via journal entries and other documents scattered around. there's an option to look at them as pure text, been seeing this a lot lately. and while it's a spooky 1st-person adventure where you communicate with ghosts, it's not scary at all. a couple really mild jump scares in one location and that's it.

it's a linear game with bigger open areas to explore, and that's where the inconsistent checkpoint-only saving becomes a problem. some locations and some events trigger a save, others don't. there's not a single checkpoint in the entire lower garden with all the branching paths, and what's more baffling (and 'explained' by the devs in the forum thread linked above) is solving a regular puzzle usually doesn't have a checkpoint either. e.g. getting out of the cellar doesn't trigger a save, even though it involves a semi-new location and a puzzle, then leaving the entire place. no, gotta chit-chat for a while and walk around until you find a checkpoint. lame.

speaking of dialog, the choice wheel sometimes has a timer, because of course, except they can be repeated over and over, so why exactly? lines can't be skipped even if listening for a second time, and while most interactions are with the mouse, here you have to press random number keys to pick what you want to say. really?

puzzle variety is another concern. most regular items will be in a puzzle box opened with simon says (tons of hammers lying about, but when you need a screwdriver, it's hidden really well and also inside a puzzle-locked box), every single gate has a rotary puzzle, and there are 9 hidden puzzle boxes, each with a lights out mechanic. basically, they took my least favorite puzzle types and plastered the game with it. hidden boxes are optional but provide a bit more background info. I missed the first, but that's what chapter selection is for. and a proper save system that this game lacks, not sure if I mentioned it.

there's a bunch of other puzzles, some relatively straightforward, others more obscure, a few even more so, but you should be able to figure them out by re-reading journal entries and looking at the puzzly object again. a list of current goals is also available, as well as a hint system, but I haven't tried it, just peeked at a walkthrough occasionally (and simply looked up all the lights out nonsense, hate it).

controls are mostly as they should be in a wasd-controlled game, right click zooms out and all that, plus everything is rebindable. don't recall jumping being necessary in the entire game, but as I said above, no reason not to sprint all the time. there's even a toggle for it, which doesn't trigger global auto-run, only while you're moving. so for the current duration you can press the toggle or hold shift, but as soon as you let go and press forward again, have to do the same. complete nonsense. even more annoying is coming out of sprinting the camera always zooms back, would've loved a toggle for that, and an fov slider too.

other smaller issues include a puzzle where mouse wheel could've rotated the pieces on top of a hotkey, and I wish the inventory were part of the notes/hints/goals screen. tab would be convenient to bring it all up and choose with the mouse, but I had to go with the second best thing: changed the notes hotkey to tilde (current ones are shown, not defaults, sadly it has to be mentioned even though it should be a given).

the presentation is mostly fine. not much variety in scenery and objects to litter the floor with, plus the almost constant darkness and later fog doesn't help either. then again, a bit of sunshine, candle-lit rooms, and even the lit-up mansion look pretty nice. there are a bunch of graphics settings too, and I could play it without issues by turning some stuff off, didn't even need the supposed minimum of 6 gb ram, nor did I notice an iota of difference. other settings include camera sensitivity and invert, resolutions, windowed mode, vsync, and brightness.

separate volume settings are also at hand, but weirdly, I found everything a bit too soft even maxed out. it's always the opposite, can't act fast enough to turn down blaring music and annoying sound effects, if the game even lets me. the protagonist did a decent job playing marie (not while reading puzzle box lore though), can't say the same about the others.

let me reiterate: the save system is crap, but it didn't cause me a lot of trouble overall, and I played the game over multiple sessions and several days. after some patches the save and load icons don't look the same anymore (who thought that was a good idea?), but they might not happen at the same time, so make sure to take a few steps after the cog icon shows up and the new location loads to actually see a disk icon and save your progress. once you're on the estate, leaving or entering the house triggers a save every time, along with some other places.

it's not unmissable and definitely not something to pay full price for (which is now half of what the original price was), but with the right expectations it's okay if you can catch it on a deep sale. it'll probably take about 8 hours, a lot more than many other similar games offer, though there's a lot of extra walking here.

Évaluation publiée le 19 mai 2019
I love puzzle adventure games à la Myst and from the trailer this game seemed like the perfect fit for me, but I sadly can't recommend it, for multiple reasons:

- Story:
I didn't find the story particularly interesting, but I guess that's a matter of opinion. What is more problematic is the way it's written. It doesn't feel like it's been written by a professional writer, which doesn't make us feel engaged in the story and makes the characters difficult to believe, with sentences like: "Today it was the first clear sky for the first time in several months".

The story is mostly told through letters that seems to have been ripped from people's diaries and, for some reason, scattered everywhere. A lot of walking simulators do this, but in this case it makes it all feel really fake since you'll often find pages saying something like "I hope this person doesn't know that I hid this object in that box", and the page is placed on the floor, right in front of said box. It feels like the people living in this world are really bad at hiding secrets, but mostly it feels like the people who made the game didn't know how to guide the player around their world in a more subtle way.

Another problem is that the game is filled with paper everywhere: on the floors, on desks, in drawers. The letters that you can read are a little different from decorative letters, but not a whole lot, so the game quickly becomes a pixel hunting game in 3d, where you need to look in every drawer (and there are a lot of drawers!) and move your mouse over every piece of paper in case one of them is important. It's even more problematic since some objects are buggy. For example, if you open the top drawer of a cabinet, as you mouse over the content of the drawer your cursor will change, telling you that there is something to click. You'll think it's a letter, only to find that it's actually the hitbox to open the drawer under it...

For the dialogues, there is a voice actress, but the problem is that the same person does all the voices. It can sometimes be confusing to know who is talking. To help with that they added subtitles that change color depending on who is talking, which is good, except for the parts where they mix up the colors, although I've only noticed this once. It's also sometimes not clear if the main character is talking to you or if it’s a non-character narrator.

Last thing with the story is that it's really bad at making you feel engaged. You start the game looking for your sister, you see her at the other side of a broken bridge, you find a way to get there and she's gone. The rest of the game you are progressing through the world to find her. The problem is that, to try to find your sister, you solve a bunch of puzzles to open doors that you know your sister can't have gone through, since the puzzles weren't solved when you got there. So for the first 5 minutes you feel like you're looking for your sister, but for the rest of the game you feel like you're wasting valuable time on side quests, helping other characters and searching rooms full of drawers to open.

- Puzzles:
The puzzles are the second most important part of this game, but they're just as bad as the story.

The game contains a lot of the puzzles we normally find in students' projets, like the puzzles where a machine plays a pattern and you need to repeat it, or puzzles where you press a button that switches the lights on the buttons around it and you need to find out how to light the whole board. There is even a gear puzzle and a pipe puzzle.

Some of those basic puzzles are even there multiple times, like the lightswitch puzzle that is there 9 times, and the repeating pattern puzzle that is there more than 3 times.

The other puzzles are a little better, but a big problem with them is that, just like the letters about hidden secrets that are placed right next to the hidden secret, puzzles often have their solution written right next to them. There is no need to search for clues or anything, it's all right there. For example, you have an inventory system, but the game could probably do without it since most of the time you'll add items to your inventory, only to place it straight away on a machine that's right next to where the items were.

Speaking of items, there is a lot of trash in this world that you can interact with, and I mean literal trash, like empty cans that you can pick up and examine for some reason. Because of that, it's often difficult to know when there are important items to find between all the trash.

Some of the puzzles and charades can also sometimes be interpreted in multiple ways, which is annoying, and some of the solutions don't make much sense. Puzzle games are my favorite type of games and I've played a ton of them, but the puzzles in this one just weren't interesting to me.

- Saving system:
The game has an autosave feature and no manual save. Normally that's not a problem because most puzzle adventure games save as soon as you change something on a puzzle, or at least as soon as you solve a puzzle or an important part of a puzzle. Lake Ridden saves... when it wants to.

Sometimes it doesn't even autosave after solving a big puzzle, like one of the big puzzles that unlock a new section. You'll solve the puzzle, but before it saves you'll need to walk 20 meters towards the next section to reach a point that triggers a save.

Another problem is that the loading icon (when it loads a new section) is placed in the same corner as the saving icon. If you look at it directly, you can tell the difference between the two, but if you're looking at the center of the screen and just see something in the corner of the screen you'll have no idea if the game was saved, or if the game is just loading the next room.

It becomes a big problem when, after solving a big puzzle, the trigger to load the next section comes before the one to save. One time I spent 15 minutes on a puzzle, started walking towards the next section, saw an icon in the corner, thought the game was saved and closed it. When I loaded back the game I saw that it hadn't saved my progress and that I needed to waste another 15 minutes to solve the puzzle once more, because the icon I saw was actually the loading icon. The trigger to save was another 10 meters after the trigger to load the next section. This is very annoying. I can't count how many times I wanted to exit the game but kept on playing simply because I wasn't sure how far back the game had last autosaved.

- Level design:
In multiple sections, especially in the first sections of the game, the level design feels like you're walking through a maze. They added a bunch of lights that you can light along your way to help you remember the places you've already visited, which helps, but a game shouldn't require you to light up hundreds of lights just so you can understand where you are going.

There are also funny directions given to you by characters, like one time when I'm coming out of a house, in the middle of a forest. It's raining and there is a lot of fog, making it hard to see, and a character tells me "the path is over there, next to the trees". I'm in a forest, of course it's next to the trees! But what trees? From the missions list, it said that I had to get to the lake, so I took the path I knew was going to the lake, but no, that wasn't the right part of the lake. It turns out there was another more hidden path leading to another side of the lake...

- Graphics:
The game doesn't look like the images on the store page. I’m not sure if they changed something to the style after the game came out or if those images are art renderings of the game, but the real game is very different. The graphics in the game are a lot less contrasted and saturated and there is more fog. It makes it look a little more realistic than in those high contrast images, but it also makes it a lot harder to see what's around you, making it even more difficult to navigate the levels.

As for the achievements, they're fairly easy to obtain, just keep your eyes open for the puzzle boxes. I've managed to 100% them in one playthrough.

This is where I wish a mixed button existed. The game wasn't bad, in fact it was really good. The narrative story telling was really interesting and relaxing to listen to. The visuals are wonderful and the soundtrack is really setting the mood. The only reason this game is getting a not recommended is because of one reason. Évaluation publiée le 26 décembre 2019
My god, that was excrutiating. I'm glad I only spent around 3 bucks on this. I wouldn't recommend it. The first 2 chapters were sorta okay, the game gradually opened up more and solving the puzzles required a modicum of thinking, but the issues overall already became quite apparent.

The journal in itself in which you gather clues, etc. is messy, it's all got way too many submenus and the information isn't condensed. So you'll often be flipping through 4 or 5 different documents. Writing the important stuff down yourself helps, but that just shouldn't be necessary.

Some puzzles are just very obscure and cryptic, especially when you've missed 1 vital clue that's been lying around the floor somewhere. One puzzle for example requires you to find 5 symbols around the room (which you will only find by chance) and then order them somehow, yet the game never gives you any hint, unless you use the inbuilt "hint" system (i.e. cheating). These hints should be told through environmental story telling, building up to the puzzle. The solution in the end was ordering them in descending order...and I was like...cool, trial and error.

Many of the other puzzles involve a lot of repetition and memorizing patterns. There's really not a lot of variation in the game, just increasingly difficult "puzzles" of the same kind. Especially terrible were the "arrangement" puzzles, where I had to sit like 5 inches away from the screen to make out the minute differences while using the mouse or controller to align several rings...

Other than that this game is just an "atmospheric" walking simulator. The graphics are quite ♥♥♥♥♥ to be honest, the atmosphere almost non-existent, the story is trash (girl goes missing, sister is looking for her and encounters other characters, who send her on a merry-go-round to find her). At no point in the game is there ever a sense of urgency portrayed by the protagonist or the other characters. This may be in part due to the bad voice acting (it's all presented in this sing-song attitude, like grandma telling her grandkids a story), but the writing isn't much help either. I didn't feel like anyone actually wanted to save the girl, least of all the protagonist...more taking a leasurely stroll.

The rest of the "subplots" if you wanna call em that don't make a good impression either. In the beginning there's something about a brother who got lost in the woods...maybe this case was supposed to be linked to the game's missing sister, but after the 2nd chapter nothing about it is ever mentioned again...same goes for the people living in the "village". Apparently there were only 4 people living there anyway...the old man's experiments? No answers either.

It wants to be mystical and threatening, I guess, but fails miserably.

And last but not least: Pointless backtracking after about the middle of the game, which kills the sense of progression, especially after having had to find the umpteenth thing for the next thing to find the next thing...I've heard Starwars Rise of Skywalker is like that as well...And without a map and very poor visibility (thanks to the "rain" and the bad graphics) it can get very hard to actually find your way around. Where the ♥♥♥♥ did Jack live again? And why is the "well in the middle of the village" INSIDE a building???

Agh. Annoying time waster. And still only about 3 ot 4 hours long.

Évaluation publiée le 25 mai 2019
I'am sure the devs meant well, but i just can't give the game a positive review, just because it dosen't have much positive in it. I would go for a neutral review if that's been possible.

The game is a mix of a Walking Simulator and a Puzzle Game. While it tries to be both at the same time, it fails in doing so greatly. It's just OK-ish in every aspect and nothing more.

There is stuff to explore like in any Walking Simulator "Game", but there is just nothing really interesting you can explore. So much stuff you can pick up, look at, but don't have any purpose. So many empty drawers to open and so many items you can't interact it in the first place. A dark, dull environment and poor graphic aren't very helpful to keep you motivated.

Story is just incredible generic and boring. It tries to be scary at times, but even fails in that department. Extremly annoying Ghosts/Spirits and uninteresting Characters all over the place. Dull notes of Lore you can find and Drawings without any connection to anything. Overall Story and the conclusion is just meh.

Puzzles are ok, but they are just very easy and the solution is most of the time right next to the puzzle itself. Which isn't that bad, but still looks like if they didn't put much thought into it. There mostly just 3 recurring puzzles you have to handle. One kind of sliding puzzle for gates to unlock, one kind of "hit buttons puzzle" to open all the optional puzzle boxes and one kind of "memorize 5-6 buttons in a row puzzle" for main story boxes to open. The just vary a little bit, but nothing more. Only interesting puzzles are those few that advance the main story. Anything else is boring, easy and uninspired.

Only real positive about it, it's over pretty soon and you can get 100% on Archivements easy, if you interested. Music is ok. Playtime is very short. Just 6-8 hours.

If you really wanna buy it wait for a heavy sale. If you don't buy it, be assured, you won't miss anything. There are just so many good puzzle games out there and even better Walking Simulators than this, if you into such things. This one is just not worth the money.

I really loved this beautiful game! The artwork here is gorgeous. The game world is pretty big, but you get a map and lamps to light the way to show where you have been.

The story is conveyed mostly through the letters and notes you find throughout the game. The story doesn’t unfold in a linear way, but they are collected in a journal and then can read them chronologically later on.

The puzzles are reasonably challenging. Not too easy and not impossible. The game has a hint system that you can use if you do get stuck. There are 9 optional puzzle boxes that have repeating puzzles that vary in complexity. Finding them and opening them, fills out the story of the owner of the estate and are worth the effort. The other puzzles were creative and fit into the premise of the story.

I really did think this game was a wonderful treat and I recommend to those that like puzzles and exploration games.

Lake Ridden
Erkundung, Rätsel

Marie ist 13 Jahre alt und geht mit ihrer Schwester Sophie und deren Freunden am Ende des Sommers noch einmal zelten. In der 2. Nacht verschwindet Sophie nach einem unnötigen kleinen Streit in den Wald und bleibt fortan verschwunden. Marie geht sie suchen und gerät unversehens in ein mysteriöses Abenteuer, in dem sie es mit kniffligen Rätseln, ungewöhnlichen Charakteren und einer Geschichte aus der Vergangenheit konfrontiert wird. Wird sie ihre Schwester wieder finden ?

Auf der Suche muss Marie einige Rätsel lösen, die z.T. recht herausfordernd sind. Mehr als einmal wollte ich die Maus in den Monitor schmeißen, aber: Beherrschung und Ruhe sind alles, und so habe ich nach rund 9 Stunden doch noch alles geschafft - und ich selbst war auch geschafft, aber ganz zufrieden.

Leider kann man keine andere Sprache auswählen, ein kleines bis mittleres Manko.

Was mir neben den Rätseln gut gefiel, war die nächtliche Illuminierung, d.h. es waren überall Lampen, Kerzen, Leuchtgloben und Laternen verteilt, die ich im anzünden konnte, und tataa, es ward Licht - ob in den Gebäuden oder draußen: es hatte was, vielleicht weil ich es selbst in der Hand hatte. Auch wenn es kein Horrorspiel ist, dunkel muss ja nicht sein...

Évaluation publiée le 17 mai 2018
Produit reçu gratuitement

Please follow our curator page: IndieGems for more reviews.
Lake Ridden is a beautiful first person puzzle adventure game. It takes place in a mystical forest. Our protagonist is trying to find her sister who ran away after an argument and got lost. While looking for your sister you stumble upon something unexpected: an old mystery and a now abandoned town deep in the woods.

I was expecting Lake Ridden to be a familiar pretty looking walking simulator type game with some light puzzling and story sprinkled on top. This game is definitely more of a puzzle adventure than a walking sim. I was actually quite surprised by the quality of the puzzles. Many puzzles are well designed and are challenging in a good way. Even when you think you know what to do, it may still take some head scratching to actually get the solution right. There are logical puzzles, riddles and object interaction puzzles similar to “The Room” series.

The story blends puzzles and locations together well. I found voice acting to be good too. It is important to note that the game does not have any horror elements, nor jump scares.

Visually the game looks good and uses lightning well. Some scenes felt a bit over-saturated and others were too foggy. Thankfully Lake Ridden has a good variety of dark and well lit, opened and closed spaces. Further in the game areas really opened up. I almost got lost.

Lake Ridden is a well-made puzzle adventure game that I can easily recommend to the fans of the genre.

Évaluation publiée le 11 juillet 2020
A tentative yes from me.
Majority of the puzzles are just the right level of difficulty so you get the satisfaction of solving them and you don't have to resort to a walkthrough every few minutes.
The area you explore is also well designed and feels like a real, lived-in place. Where the game falls down is in its story. It starts well enough with you and your sister going camping, and then suddenly find she has left in the night. You catch glimpses of her in the wood, and it clear she isn't sleepwalking, she's been possessed or drawn by something. And then in chasing after her you fall into the main bulk of the game, and the whole urgency of finding your sister falls by the wayside as you do nonsensical oddjobs for some roaming spirits. And the voice acting is pretty atrocious altogether. Really jars with the tone of the game. So by the end I wasn't invested at all, the only thing keeping me going were the puzzles.
So a recommendation with caveats.

Évaluation publiée le 18 mai 2018
Produit reçu gratuitement

感谢17173萤火虫提供的游戏。

简介：
故事的背景设立在1988年，在美国缅因州茂密的森林中，你扮演十三岁的女孩Marie，与她的妹妹Sofia以及一些朋友一起露营。姐妹之间的一场争执使得妹妹跑走，消失在了迷雾之中。在寻找妹妹Sofia的途中，你偶然发现了一片充满神秘色彩的古老庄园，并由此展开了一段梦幻般的超自然冒险。

关键词：冒险，解谜，氛围

游戏特色：
+ 绝佳的氛围营造

尽管沐浴在日光下的森林很迷人，但在多数时候，游戏是在夜间进行的。因为缺少光线，Lake Ridden很容易被误认为是恐怖游戏，绝对不是。这片森林并不危险，反而充满了奇迹与秘密。在朦胧的暮色笼罩下，静谧的森林散发出一丝诡异。高大的松树向璀璨的星空延伸，萤火虫在花丛间飞舞，脚步声与小动物的叫声在耳畔萦绕，填补了柔缓，近乎空灵的配乐之间的空隙。

+ 精巧的地图设计

Lake Ridden的地图很小，但是各种机关和密道将空间充分利用，让你误以为自己处在广阔的世界，就像一个外表平常但内藏玄机的盒子。在游戏 艾迪芬奇的记忆 里，整个家族的故事，都浓缩在一栋建筑中，二者有异曲同工之妙（尽管如此，后者“盒子”的内部构造要高超许多）。

+ 疯狂古怪的解谜

奇异的花园，通过网格移动玩具船，书柜内的组合锁，祭坛与神秘仪式，古怪的谜题给游戏增添了神秘色彩，新奇的机制足以让你沉浸其中。所有的线索总是包含在同一个区域，所以你不必回溯太多。

如果在解谜过程遭遇瓶颈，你可以使用每个谜题中的四个提示来获取帮助。提示只会引导你寻找答案而不是直接揭晓答案，即使使用全部提示，仍然需要进一步的思考，因此这不会过大地打击你解决谜题后的成就感。

除了主线上的解谜，游戏里散布着9个机关盒。这些盒子里分别放着不同的照片，一旦解锁就会有一段对照片的讲述来进一步扩充剧情。

+ 与其他角色交互

Nora与这座古老庄园的神秘过往有关。因为她的加入，你不会因为独自探索而感到孤单。，虽然你看不见她，但她会和你交谈并引导你如何行动。和Firewatch不同的是，对话都是预先设定好的，无法选择，但对话过程里的提问环节能提高参与感。

当你选择某个选项时，面板不会消失，所以你可以问完所有的问题。Nora提供的信息，Marie的内心独白和她沿路找到的线索，不断引导着你走进这个神秘的世界，并开始解开这一系列相互关联的秘密。

-- 声音缺乏情感

尽管环境文字，如日记，信件中描述使这个故事得到补充，但对话的语调与之不匹配。比如主角Marie在遇到不同情况时，她的语调缺乏变化，没能很好地表达诸如疑虑或紧张等等的情绪， 没有起到烘托情景的作用。

-- 剧情的代入感不强
小时候，你是否做过这样的梦，梦境如此真实就像真的发生过一样？这句话是引自游戏开头的提问。推动游戏进展的有两条线索，明线是找妹妹，暗线则是与一个神秘世界发生的交互。游戏想要营造一种幻境，所有这些经历似乎存在过，又似乎从未发生。但通关之后，这场南柯一梦没有给我留下很深刻的影响，一种说不上来的感觉，有些平淡，代入感不强。

总结：
初见商店截图还以为是步行模拟类游戏，结果发现是冒险解谜类。游戏的氛围烘托得很出色，营造出一种神秘之感。虽然是夜间，但无需为此感到恐惧。谜题新奇古怪而不刁钻，且与游戏主题契合得很好。地图设计上，暗道和机关引人称赞也让人迷路。当你越发接近真相时，你的疑惑也会增加，玩到后面会有一丝压抑的，而人物之间的对话能在一定程度上缓解这种孤独感。美中不足的是剧情没能给我留下很深的印象。

评分：7.5 / 10


更多游戏推荐请关注17173萤火虫鉴赏家

Évaluation publiée le 23 janvier 2020
Seriously, what did I just play?

This game looks really amazing. It seemed like it was going to be everything I've ever looked for in a game. But that story. I can't get past how convoluted and borderline nonsensical it was. I'm all for supernatural/paranormal elements, but this just didn't make sense, or rather very little effort was made to explain what was actually happening in a way that made me care about any of it. And seriously the protagonist was just way too laid back about everything that was happening. Suddenly being able to communicate with ghosts/spirits? Stumbling upon a little lost town in the woods? Finding human remains? Her sister being gone without a trace for apparent days? Why was she not showing any emotion about any of this??? The whole thing felt a little juvenile to me, and the unenthusiastic voice acting didn't help.

Don't get me wrong, I loved the puzzles. Most of them were really great on their own, challenging enough to be satisfying and thought-provoking but definitely not impossible. I especially enjoyed those in the first half or so of the game. Once more elements of the "story" were introduced there were attempts made to tie the puzzles more closely in with the plot, and it just felt kind of forced to me. Add that to the fact that eventually the entire game is just running back and forth across an area that's visually redundant to begin with, and I wound up being pretty disappointed overall. I would love to see the creators of this game take a crack at something that focuses more on just puzzles and less on a bizarrely woven together narrative because I'm sure it would be great. But this really didn't do it for me.

Évaluation publiée le 14 mai 2022
Lake Ridden is an exploration puzzle game with a light story.

The attention to detail is great and everything looks fantastic—the best I’ve seen in a while in an indie game '[in '2018']'. The puzzles are a mix of classic ones with a twist, some new ones, and some inventory-based, but also with some repetition. The story wasn’t anything too impressive, but okay. The music was mostly a relaxing background thing.
I recommend playing—although not so much for the story, but for the puzzles and the exploration.

The voice acting was competent, but sometimes also a bit emotionless or hysterically cheerful.

The story felt like a bit of a mess: It started as a typical horror story, with people gone missing etc, and then changed into more of a children’s ghost fairytale. Events and characters from the first part were suddenly dropped. The story felt more like a mere container for the puzzles. This unfortunately made me lose a bit of interest around three quarters into the game, so for the last part I wasn’t as invested as I had been.

Once, when starting the game, I got a black screen and had to restart, after which everything functioned as expected.

The puzzles didn't always make sense. Some repetition and running back and forth all over the map.

Final words: If you want to go explore a fantastically realized mansion and solve some puzzles, this is the perfect game for you: there is lots to explore and be challenged by. Just don’t expect too much from the story; it’s an okay fairytale, but that’s about it.

Full review:
https://maskinkultur.com/2018/05/18/review-lake-ridden/

Évaluation publiée le 19 mai 2018
After about 6 hours, I've just completed all the achievements for this game. Lake Ridden is a mystery puzzle game that focuses a lot on atmosphere and mood, but is still challenging in places.

Best parts:
- Great scenery, including suitably spooky weather which changes throughout the game
- Interesting and challenging puzzles with a good hint system
- A large area to explore with lots of lore to discover

Minor complaints:
- Some secondary puzzles are reused past the point where they're interesting, particularly the "puzzle boxes"
- There is one puzzle that amounts to "read the developer's mind" - i.e. guess semi-randomly until you get the answer
- At a couple of points the "atmospherically dark" lighting reaches the point of "I can't see anything at all"
- The open world portion has no map and few shortcuts, so there's more than a little annoying backtracking, especially in the middle of the game
- Game lags noticeably when you enter a new area
- While the game saves all the lore notes during a session, it doesn't keep them if you close the game and reload, which is a shame - I wanted to go through and try and discover all the letters.

Évaluation publiée le 6 mars 2020
先说个忧伤的事，这个游戏的制作组因为销量不佳而倒闭，所以就不会有官中了，游戏中文本量还是挺多的，在解谜卡住的时候，提示信息还是很重要的，但到目前为止没有汉化组有做这游戏的汉化补丁，这也导致玩这游戏的玩家并不多！
做为一个步行模拟游戏来说，游戏还是非常出色的，无论是氛围的营造，空间的利用，谜题的设计，剧情的展开，都属一流，抛开解谜的部分游戏可以类比下《艾迪芬奇的记忆》，而这个谜题还真是有点难，有些还是误打误撞完成的，但也花费了大量时间！九个密码箱也是伤透脑筋，虽然有方法，但我并不熟啊……很多解谜，都还要自带做笔记，但基本还是知道思路，这也是制作组牛逼的地方，给了你线索，需要你自己再琢磨！
游戏虽然大部分都在比较昏暗的环境下，但是并没有一点点吓人的内容，一路点灯，星星点点，还挺浪漫的……（喂，不是要找妹妹嘛）游戏里还有与鬼魂用打字机交流的戏份，理应很恐怖吧，然后并没有呢，还带了一点破案的内容……这游戏包含的要素真的多！
通关给人一种如释重负的感觉，终于不用再受谜题折磨了，游戏中实际全成就都完成了，但不知道为啥有个密码盒全解锁的成就没完成，明明都解锁了！游戏最近进了IG包，应该有不少小伙伴有了吧，Steam商城史低12元，个人觉得还是值这个价的，只是谜题容易劝退啊~~~

Évaluation publiée le 30 janvier 2020
Produit reçu gratuitement

Lake Ridden is unlike most other Atmospheric Puzzle games I've come across. I typically enjoy these style of experiences, when done right. I've jumped in and out of Lake Ridden multiple times now, and I just can't find a solid reason to approve it.

On the one hand, it tries to deliver a compelling story of discovering the whereabouts of your lost sister, which was captivating at first. I very much commend the developers for creating puzzle that are actually fairly challenging and force the player to think outside the box a bit. The issue I kept running into was the amount of backtracking involved. Backtracking that involved areas with very little to no points of interest. No map or markers to speak of either. There is a way to allow the games to help solve puzzles, thankfully. Yet I found using these clues ultimately watered down the best part of the game. The times I used it convinced me that I just wanted to further the story. I was losing interest because pacing was becoming affected. That is problem in games focused on delivering a good story.

Ultimately, there will be those who love the challenge of the puzzles and the bleak atmosphere. I did not become one of those people. I appreciate everything that they created within this world, but I wanted out after circling the main hub a dozen times.

Recommandé
11.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 mai 2019
The game could be described as a walking sim with puzzle solving along the way and is pretty much linear in its completion. If you enjoyed Quern, I think you should enjoy this game too.

For the first few hours of gameplay, you follow your sister's trail as she mysteriously wandered off in the woods. Then you finally reach a mansion and the ghost town next to it where the rest of the game follows and concludes. As the story unfolds, a few more areas are unlocked there, but you will mostly move back and forth between them. Also, let's note that even if you will encounter different ghosts during the game, there is absolutely nothing scary in this game. This is not an horror game.

Puzzles

I am not sure which category of players was targeted by this game, but players used to puzzle games might be disappointed as most puzzles are quite straightforward in their resolution. Only in the end, when you reach the island area, will you get the most interesting puzzles in the game. But beware that a good understanding of English is necessary to solve those puzzles.

Exploration

If you want to better understand the story, a bit of exploration is necessary. Letters, drawing and photos are scattered all over the place. You will have to open every drawers, inspect every corner in order to find any document that will tell you more about the very excentric owner of the mansion (the inventor who made all those puzzles the player has to solve) and the different staff members working on the estate.

Graphics

The least I can say is that the game is really pretty. A strange thing is that we can only use a lantern (which is only found when we arrive at the mansion) inside buildings but never outside. But I guess it is an aesthetic choice from the devs. There are hundreds of candles and lanterns everywhere that are beautifully lighting the path and also give a bit of an eerie feeling to the game.

Saving

The shortcoming of the game is that the save system is kind of flawed. The game uses automatic saves that can only be activated at some location, after you solve some puzzle (but not for all puzzles) or when you reach some new dialogue event (but not always). That is kind of cumbersome as you can not save whenever you want. The best alternative I found was to go back to one of the location save points I had previously encountered (mostly in town or in the mansion).

Main pros:
- Atmosphere and world
- Some interesting puzzle concepts

Main ♥♥♥♥:
- Short game (3-5 hrs)
- A lot of backtracking during parts of the game
- Poor narrative
- Confusing story wrap-up by end
- Linear puzzles and linear progression

This game has some very lovley scenery and a really good atmosphere. Walking around and taking in the sights is a big part of the experience.

The puzzles are in my opinion too few and far between and they are quite linear in layout. I found the difficulty of the puzzles to be easy-moderate. That being said most puzzle designs where different and interesting.

I did not find the story and narrative that compelling. However it did build an interesting mystery during the first parts of the game, I found it did poorly trying to resolve this mystery by the end, rushing through poorly narrated exposition with obvious plot twists. The voice acting was decent if perhaps alittle shrill and grating. The narrative was also quite "hand holdy", often unnessearily having the main character stating the obvious.

I was disappointed with how short this game was. I completed this game in 4.5 hrs and found all the "hidden" puzzle boxes.

I would be very hesitant with recommending this game. If you're looking to buy it, be aware that it's more in the style of something like "The Vanishing of Ethan Carter" or "Firewatch" then a Myst-like puzzle game.

Évaluation publiée le 11 mai 2018
I didn't write too many reviews of games yet, but I'll put my thoughts into order for this one:

What started out with paralells to "Through the Woods" quickly evolved from a walking simulator to a first person puzzle game. You still find snippets of journals/letters, but part of the story is also acted out vocally, which makes the characters more relatable than just plain text.

Visually the scenes convey mostly calmness, a bit of lonelyness and at points coldness, until you light the lamps/candles all around (seriously, there are hundreds of them XD). Also stylewise the game was pretty well realized, to be close to realistic, but not in a way that makes some other games' textures look like imported photos.
The ambience is subtle, calm, soothing, always there, but never really diverting your attention from the task at hand.


The puzzles come in multiple varieties, some repeat, but many are unique. Those unique puzzles can be a bit harder, not only needing one layer, but two layers of hints, which you can get from journals, letters, environment etc.
I really liked that you could "revisit" most of the gameworld, even at a later stage, just to see, if you happened to miss anything (or experience the place in a different light), since in many games you are just pushed down a linear path and never get to catch up on collectibles you missed, unless you started an old savefile or from chapter selection.

Overall, it was a fun and at times, challenging trip, with some very interesting characters.
Also the soundtrack will be part of my work playlist now :D

Évaluation publiée le 30 septembre 2021
This game is quite good. Wish I could say it is great or awesome, but sadly, I can't. It had a lot of potential, and did many things right, but there are also many things that simply keep it from being the awesome game it could have been. A few examples of that:
- The graphics are gorgeous, everything looks really nice, there's a lot of variety everywhere. However, it lags quite a bit, no matter the quality (I have a geforce 1050ti, not the best, but not bad either, and I usually can run games like this one with max quality or so), and for the size it has, variety isn't enough: e.g. there are tons and tons of books, but they are all the same, over and over; tons and tons of drawers to open, but they all contain the same stuff, no matter where they are located (maybe leaving most of them empty would have been better, since this breaks immersion a bit); a lot of flowers and vegetation, but also mostly the same, repeated over and over, etc.
- Some puzzles are great, ingenious, different from the ones you find in these kinds of games (and I've played a bunch of them); I totally loved them. However, others are very common, and are found many many times over in the game, enough to get you to hate them (the puzzles boxes you find all have an obnoxious flipping things puzzle; once I was tired, and couldn't find the solution, I lost a whole hour trying to figure it out, and ended up doing it in 5 mins the next day; I never wanted to see them again, however it was the third one out of nine!!). Most are very very logical and reasonable, and yet there are one or two that don't make sense (one in particular, a sort of "detective" puzzle, makes 0 sense for a number of reasons, both as a puzzle, and story-wise).
- The story is intriguing, mysterious, engaging; and yet can be incredibly vague, to the point where I'm not sure I fully got it after having finished the game. Also, a lot of it is found through notes, which can be out of order, so you have to find all of them and reread them in order, which is a bit obnoxious. Also, you can't reorder them, and they show up in your notebook in the place where you found them, instead of in the order required to read them properly; this is something that should be relatively easy to fix and improve.
- The size of the world is perfect for exploration; not too big, but not too small; properly delimited so not to explore things that weren't meant to be explored, and every place (or every relevant place at least) can be visited again before the end of the game, in case you missed anything. However, most of the stuff there is to find can be found by simply following the story, and so exploring is not as rewarding as it could have been. I think a bit more stuff to find would have been nice.
- Characters are mostly great and very interesting, but they could have been explored a bit more; e.g. one of them is barely mentioned, yet played an intricate role in the story.

The game may still get updated and improved, its last update was in march, so it is not abandoned. However, I think most of these things will probably remain unchanged. It makes sense, after all "a work of art is never complete, it is merely abandoned", however it is a bit sad, because this had the potential to be an awesome exploration game, and it fell a bit flat.
Yet, all in all, I enjoyed the game, and I recommend you give it a go, just don't expect this one to be the next "Firewatch" xD.
 
fredling192

Produit reçu gratuitement

I spent about 7 hours playing through the game on twitch over a couple of sessions. I do enjoy puzzle games however if the puzzles feel forced I often end up struggling to get to the end.

Although there are a couple of repeated themes for the puzzles revolved around puzzle boxes that flesh out the story the puzzles that actually progress the story were unique and fit well within the narrative. In fact everything fit together well and made sense. The game also has a built in hint system for these main puzzles that I used a couple of times to help things along. The story flows at a decent pace and the voice acting is well done. I collected all achievements during 1 playthrough and the game has no real replayability however I enjoyed my time with the game and find it worth the asking price.

Games like this are a welcomed break between all the heavy combat focused titles we have these days. I look forward to seeing what Midnight Hub come up with next.

Évaluation publiée le 30 juin 2019
Do not be fooled by the professional review, Lake Ridden does not resemble Myst. The environments appear interesting at first. Once you realize how often the same decorative objects are used, the game begins to feel cluttered. The feeling worsens as you're sent from one end of the map to the other, over and over, to achieve bit parts of a larger fetch quest. Only a handful of the puzzles are varied and engaging. The remaining puzzle boxes and Simon Says music box puzzles which are scattered throughout the map are repetitive, giving all but the most dedicated binge gamers a reason to take a break when found. If you aren't drawn in by the narrative storytelling, this title offers little else.

Évaluation publiée le 11 mai 2018
Produit reçu gratuitement

Click for full review here with pictures. Many thanks to Midnight Hub for providing me with a copy of the game.
http://theindiediary.co.uk/reviews/lake-ridden/

In Lake Ridden. You play as a young girl, who is trying to find her younger sister after she goes missing on a camping trip.
Along the way, you find an abandoned estate. Here is where you will look for clues to find your sister. As well as trying to solve an entire other mystery of the estate’s past.

I have read a lot of things written about Lake Ridden that have the words ‘walking simulator’ in them. Though I do enjoy a good walking sim like Dear Esther or Gone home. I have to say, this is not one of those. Lake Ridden is most definitely a puzzle-adventure game first and foremost. Once you get into the meat and bones of the game, there is no linear path like in those titles. Instead, what we have here is something more reminiscent of Myst or Obduction. There are puzzles galore here. Many, many, MANY, puzzles within the game. And a large area to explore along with them.


From the beginning, I had a good feeling about the game. I began in a forest, and my sister had run off. I could see her at the other end of a broken bridge. Of course I knew by the time I got round there she would be gone (otherwise this would have been one heck of a short game hehe). But this was me off on my adventure to locate my little sis. Along the dark paths I began igniting the lanterns I came across to light the way. Which only added to each area’s beauty with the gorgeous orange glow they gave off, tinting all that is near. And it wasn’t long before I was introduced to some of the early puzzles. And I have to say, I was impressed, but more excited for what may come.

Throughout the early stages of the game, lovely melodic music played that fitted perfectly. I then noticed that in each new area I discovered, a new piece of music would begin to play. And each was as soothing as the last. The soundtrack in Lake Ridden gives the player that great sense of wonder & mystery. And honestly, it doesn’t stop til the game is finished. So bravo to the composer.


We are introduced to a few different voiced characters in the game. All of which do a solid job, and help to paint the story along with notes scattered throughout the world. Some of the characters we learn about are very interesting. And the developers did a great job with the story, as I found myself ‘needing’ to know more about them. And what happened here.

Now for the main substance of the game. Once I made it to the mansion, this is where exploration opened right up for me. And the puzzles start to come thick and fast. And each puzzle feels carefully planned out. They are all very impressive. For someone that loves puzzle-adventure titles. This was a real treat for my eyes and mind. There are quite a few puzzles that require locks to be opened, but all have you doing varying things to open each one. Some of the puzzles involve searching for symbols in bookcases. Making potions to see certain things more clearly. Playing board games, searching for clues through notes, building equipment, fixing pipes with individual parts, aligning magical lights into patterns and……..well you get the picture. And these are just off the top of my head. There is a looooot of things to do in Lake Ridden. I was stumped so many times, but persevered without the hints (of which there are plenty for those that have had enough of pulling their hair out), as I find that to be part of these games. To hit points where you are completely stuck. As this only makes it even more rewarding when you finally solve it on your own.


The game world itself is set in a dark lovecraftian-like space. Dark misty forests, Old abandoned haunted buildings. And the lighting is fantastic too. Lighting torches & lanterns and candles give off the most exquisite orange glow that really compliments the entire world so well. Many rooms and areas are off limits for a while, which only added to the mysteriousness of it all. I needed to know what was behind every door, or what was locked behind every gate (Usually being a wonderful puzzle to solve).

Of course it is not without it’s faults. Some of the later areas feel too blurry when there is foggy scenes. And trying to remember where certain areas or rooms are can lead to you running around like a headless chicken for a while. I also found the dreamscape world to be quite empty. With mostly just trees and no foliage or objects in them. I think these areas could have done with more detail to them. But all in all it’s been quite the positive experience, and none of these things really impacted my fun.

When I finally finished the story. I felt a real sense of accomplishment and closure. I was also left wanting more. Mind you, this is quite a large game for this genre. It took me around 9-10 hours of gameplay. But I wanted more only because the puzzles in the game were splendid. I now look forward to whatever adventure Midnight Hub decide to embark on next.


Conclusion

An adventure full of magic, wonder & excitement. Brim-filled with unique and interesting puzzles & a fun mystery to solve. Though some parts will have you doing a lot of back-tracking & you may get completely lost at times. That is also part of the charm of these games. If puzzle-adventure games is your thing. Then this is most definitely worthy of your collection.

8.5/10
 
crazycupmuffin

Évaluation publiée le 3 juin 2020
Among different walking sims Lake Ridden can be placed above average. The game excells where other such games fail miserably, but unfortunately it has one flaw that is almost characteristic for the whole genre. But let's start with positives - there is enough puzzles and interactions in this game, that you could in fact call it a short adventure game. There's still a lot of walking, watching the views and listening to narration like in the true walking sim, but game gets pretty interesting thanks to those riddles. But the 'walking' part is also very pleasent for the eye - let me tell you the atmosphere in the game is amazing. The graphics are decent and the places you get to visit are well designed and diverse. You visit mysterious forest in the night, abandoned mansion or rocky shore covered in fog. And all those places look great! With all of this Lake Ridden could be a perfect game, but unfortunately the story is - as always - convoluted mess. I'm so tired of the stories in game that are not well thought amalgamation of cliches. And the only way to hide their poorly constructed plot is thorugh vague notes, understatements and leaving everything to your own interpretation. This is just lazyness and lack od originality, not good example for mystery story. There are plenty of games (and books or movies) that have everything well thought out and still leave room for interpretation. We should not finish the game thinking 'what was all this about, what actually happened?'. But still - Lake Ridden is worth playing. If you like this genre, check it out - you won't regret it.

Évaluation publiée le 13 mai 2018
Do you like puzzle games with story and exploration? Here's a game for you.

So how're the puzzles? There are some reoccuring pattern matching-type ones in various forms, with the main puzzles having quite a degree of variety to them, and there are plenty of them. This isn't "The Witness" though, the puzzles have meaning in the environment and story, it's not just a fun house of meaningless puzzles to solve. There was only one puzzle that I got super-stuck with, but there is an on-demand hint system to help you out.

How's the story? It certainly kept me interested enough, and I won't mention specifics as to not spoil it, but the game is certainly driven very much by the story.

Exploration? The graphics/style are very nice to look at, though not gob-smackingly jaw-dropping like "The Vanishing of Ethan Carter". You can poke around in various rooms and environments to find more stuff to read and look at, as well as turn on every candle and light you can see, prettying up the environment even more. The weather and time-of-day changes throughout as well.

My only major gripe is the lack of FOV control, though the default is just-about acceptable. Bit irritating though, as I did ask about it when they demoed it at EGX, and they said it would be added!

Overall, recommended for people who like these kinds of games.

Évaluation publiée le 4 juillet 2020
EDIT: The developer has responded and lowered the price to £10. I find this much more reasonable and removes my main gripe about the game so have changed my recommendation to suit this.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
Unfortunately I don't think I can recommend this game at full price. I picked it up for around £2.50 in the summer sale and am not too bothered to pay that, but a standard price of £20 is just too much.

Graphics/atmosphere wise, the game is lovely. I really enjoyed the ambient soundscape that added to the vibes nicely.

Puzzles are okay. There's decent variety but unfortunately a lot can just be brute forced. However there is a good inventory/notes/hint system that makes things easy to keep track of.

Voice acting was okay. There were times when things were happening that should have been distressing or scary to characters, and they were responding chirpily and blandly. I realise this was done by a small team though and have definitely heard a lot worse elsewhere.

The story is kind of where it majorly falls flat. Without spoilers, it was pretty nonsensical and vague, leaving no real sense of urgency, threat or motivation. This is my biggest reason why I think the full price is just too much to pay.

To conclude: if you like indie puzzlers, go for it. But go for it on sale.

I also love the fact that using pen and paper helps and i recommend you have them nearby if you play.

Évaluation publiée le 16 mai 2018
Lake Ridden was a lovely surprise while it lasted. The story was engaging and a nice mix of voiceover and eerie journals and other things to read. It has a very distinct Myst feel even though the world is a bit more comprehensible. The puzzles are mostly challenging and rewarding, although I found it was easy to guess on a couple toward the end that took away from that a little.

The music is deceptively light at times, but it introduces this great dynamic of making you feel comfortable as if you're wrapped in its familiarity and then shattering that when you hear some wild animal screeching out in the woods. Maybe it's not for everyone, but it worked for me and was a nice change of pace from the "this is a spooky game, and you're going to know it" motif and was a pleasant surprise that it was.

That's the other thing; this game has a horror element to it. There are a few jump scares, but mostly it comes from a scary and ominous atmosphere. Mainly, this is thanks to the storyline and the loneliness of walking around this once inhabited desolate world.

Now, minor spoilers here, so if you plan to play this to experience it yourself (and you should), then stop reading and give it a go. This is also where pretty much my only gripe is. The game starts pretty linearly, go here, figure out how to open this door, rinse and repeat. Then the game opens up and lets you walk around this abandoned town, in some of the buildings, and a mansion on the hill (which you revisit from time to time). I felt like after the second or third time backtracking between the two and spending 30 or so minutes to solve a puzzle, the pace slowed too much, especially in the later game. At a certain point I just wanted to figure things out or have another major plot point introduced, but instead, I felt like I was spinning my wheels and hoping for the end instead of enjoying it. And that's the other thing; the game is kind of short. It took me 7 hours to complete in two sittings. It's not that it needed to be longer and again, it would have called for a new plot point to make it worthwhile, but I would love to have seen another new area and have different puzzle variety to tackle. Perhaps this could be solved with DLC, where you can play a different storyline in the same world. I'm not sure of the dev's plans for the games, but one could only hope.

I also had a glitch where I stopped playing after the basement area, and when I came back the game wouldn't trigger the next objective, so I had to replay the previous chapter to fix it. I'm sure not everyone will encounter this, but worth mentioning. Also, don't look at the chapter selection if you don't want to know where you go next. For some reason it lists all the areas of the game even if you haven't gotten that far yet.

In summary and gripes aside, this game is absolutely worth playing if you like atmosphere puzzlers with an engaging story. The price may be high for some but at the very least add it to your wishlist and buy it on sale and prepare to immerse yourself in its bleak and gorgeous world.
 
Un développeur ou une développeuse a répondu à cette évaluation

Lake Ridden is a charming little first-person mystery solving puzzler. A fairly rudimentary premise is given life and intrigue thanks to its secluded setting and excellent puzzles. 7 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Non recommandé
6.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 octobre 2018
Boorish, nonsensical walking simulator-puzzler

Lake Ridden's premise sets the scene for something dreary and whimsical. In the year 1988, a woman named Marie is out in the woods camping with others. Marie's little sister, Sofia, runs off and disappears into the misty wood, forcing the former to look for her. The story then slowly unravels sequence-by-sequence into a garbled affair with invisible spirits who force Marie into doing busywork fetchquests and solving a variety of puzzles. The sombre tale ends happily, but without explicit clues of what just happened. This is partly because of the presentation, or lack off it thereof, since all the characters are invisible. Marie also has no body of own. Sofia is only briefly seen at the beginning of the game. With the spirits not having a shape in most of the scenes, it is difficult to feel invested and emotionally attached to the story. Most of the story is presented with a voice-over style commentary, leaving much of it for the player to imagine. Perhaps this design choice was dictated by lack of funds, time constraints, or something else. All in all, a voice-over story exposition commentary just doesn't cut the mustard, especially with practically no visible characters on the screen at any time.

The audiovisual design is good. The game can look great during the night scenes with foggy woods, gardens full of thorns, and abandoned shacks just standing in time. There are some fps drops during sequences when the player enters from one location to another (for e.x. climbs into an attic of a house), but these are nothing to be worried about. The ambient, peaceful musical score accompanies the game perfectly whether you are searching your surroundings or trying to figure out a solution to a tricky puzzle.

The puzzles themselves are, sadly, a hit-or-miss affair. The 9 optional puzzle boxes represent some of the most entertaining puzzle design in the game, but can be skipped entirely if wanted. The gains to be had here are just some bits of story exposition which are not crucial to the plot. The other puzzles are largely divisive. Some of them are tedious and plain annoying, like door lock puzzles with round discs. With these, you have a disc with many spinning outer layers which need to be spun correctly to make a sign or figure. There are a bunch of others varying from sensible and understandable to the kinds which make you use a guide or a wiki. I had to check a guide for some of the puzzles, and even watching the right solution I still had no idea what kind of logic the game devs were trying to follow. The logic at display was very skewed at best. Granted there is a hint system in place. You are not penalized for using this, but the system ultimately fails to provide insight into the puzzles when it's most desperately needed. Especially later on, the game has a knack for making the player run around collecting items and doing fetchquest busywork that amounts to annoying padding of the overall length.

The price is also a point of contention. For a meager 6 hours, 20 euros is a rather steep price. There is practically no replay value here whatsoever, with anyone being able to get 100% of the achievements pretty easily on the first run.

Altogether, Lake Ridden looks and sounds good, but falls short of any sort of greatness because of its tedious puzzle design, arbitrary story with no visible on-screen characters, and a high price point. If you absolutely must experience this trip, do so only during a deep, deep sale.

Pros:
+ Beautiful audiovisual presentation
+ Some great puzzles

♥♥♥♥:
- Lacklustre, humdrum story which is not even properly presented on-screen
- High price for only 6 hours
- Counterintuitive puzzle design
- Fetchquests

This game is one of the most stunning looking game i've ever played. This is a nice and chill game to experience if you have few hours to spend. You can easily complete the a 100% playthrough in about 4-5 hours if you take your time and look carefully around you. The puzzles are very easy at the beginning and they get more challenging towards the end, but you can solve them without problems with some decent logic. There is nothing scary about this game, but sometimes the eerie atmosphere is filled with a strange feeling washing over you. Overall, this game is a great 8/10, not worth the price though. Probably suggest to get it on sale.

4.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 mai 2022
Before you hate on my review, note that I maintain the group for this game genre (jokingly called "Walking simulators"[http//%26quot%3BWalking+simulators%26quot%3B]. Sadly this one is exactly what people fear this type of game is when they hear the name: dull, uninspired and boring.

These games are extremely story rich, they must be in fact, as there is no action to speak of. "Lake ridden" uses puzzles to break the monotony of its generic , bland environments. These puzzles are extremely repetitive - meaning they used the same puzzle, with the same design, in a slighly different configuration, over and over throughout.

It's lazy - just like everything else in here: generic assets, terrible landscapes, irritating mazes and puzzles you played 100 times before. It's so sad something like that was released when we have gems out there like the Stanley Parable, Everyone is gone to the rapture or the mother of all walking sims, "Dear Esther".

Major thumb down for me. Feels more like a student project than a genuine game.

Évaluation publiée le 28 mai 2020
Des Öfteren muss man einiges an Wegstrecke wieder zurücklaufen. Ich hatte das Gefühl, dass ich aus der Gegend mit dem Estate, der Laundry, etc... gar nicht mehr wegkam. Weil man ständig zu dem Haus muss, was erledigen und dann wieder zu dem Haus, bei dem man schon war, nochmal was erledigen. Nur, um dann nochmal alles wieder zurückzulaufen, weil man dann wieder dort, wo man eben schon war nochwas erledigen muss.
Locker die Hälfte aller Rätsel sind - für mich zumindest - völlig unlogisch gewesen.
Beispiel:

In einen Ofen habe ich 10 Kohlestücke reingelegt, dann angezündet - 10 Sekunden später war der Ofen aus. Ich konnte ihn nicht mehr anzünden, ohne erneut Kohlestückchen reinzulegen. Ich hab dann mal nur 2 Kohlestückchen reingelegt, da brannte der Ofen über 1 Stunde lang. Wahrscheinlich brennt der jetzt immer noch.... Sowas ist absurd und total unlogisch!
Ja, das Spiel hat eine "Hint-Funktion", aber ich wollte die nicht nutzen, da ich nachvollziehbare und logische Rätsel gut finde. Aber beides suchte ich in diesem Spiel vergebens.
Dann der Name des Spiels: LAKE Ridden. Lake = See. Aber von dem See bekommt man nicht viel mit, bzw. damit hat man nicht viel zu tun. Wieso nennt man dann das Spiel so?!
Furchtbar. Finger weg!

Évaluation publiée le 14 mai 2018
Produit reçu gratuitement

7-9 hours of gameplay? Naw, I left this game on for about 3 hours paused, and completed all the content.

Every single "bonus" puzzle was the exact same puzzle, with the "reward" of poorly delivered lines from the main character. Between the "setpieces" there were a total of 3 different types of puzzle, with nothing added. The writing in this game may have been better than it seemed to me(it seemed not great), but only because of the horrid delivery by the voice actors. Strictly linear gameplay, with a heap of backtracking, I spent more time walking than doing puzzles.

?kinda? spoilers below(not really)
Repeated puzzles-
All basic, literally never any challenge
Simon Says
Flip all the tiles, all tiles next to one you click are the ones to flip
Line up art on concentric circles

You will do quite a few of these, and they are always the same except maybe the art is mostly mirrored on the circles, or the Simon Says is longer, or the flip puzzle is bigger.
Set Peices -
There were some okay ones where you have to use context clues to figure stuff out, but mostly they were too easy, while I did get stuck a couple times for a short while, it usualy wasnt solved by anything clever.

I'm only going to list the first few puzzles here

Gate code - Use basic maths
Runes - Liked this one, if not for all the walking
Riddles - Impossibly vague minus the obvious one, and somehow not hard, oh look more walking
Attic code - Pretty good puzzle, nothing explicit
Attic box - Okay
Attic table - the only hard part is finding out the order
Island bones - Guess what shapes represent parts of a story, or maybe not, I got it on my first try.

3/10
Remove all the story and voice acting and walking around and it would be a 5/10

So-so puzzle/exploration game. 6/10.

The Good:
-Most puzzles are manageable and interesting
-Good graphics/environment
-Easy controls
-Somewhat interesting plot

Needs Improvement:
-Some puzzles made no logical sense
-A map is really needed. You are told to go to the "Laundry," which is one of several identical looking crumbling buildings. You also meander along paths without any idea where they go.
-Plot is bizarre. I didn't have the patience to read pages and pages of journals to understand it.
-Walking speed is slow.
-Very cloudy and dark. I like exploration games where I can actually see what I am doing.

Buy it if it's on sale for $5 or less.

7.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 avril 2021
The game is very fun and well put together.

One thing to watch out for is although it has many puzzles, most are fairly trivial and there IS a good deal of walking and exploring. I would consider this a "walking simulator with puzzles" as opposed to a "puzzle game with some walking".

It can get frustrating at times because you have to run your cursor over EVERYTHING to make sure you don't miss a clue, and this game suffers from "too much stuff" in the game. There's a ton of set dressing, random items you can pickup, and a plethora of drawers you can open (all stuffed to the gills with stuff you can't pick up, but 1/30 WILL have some random clue or note you'll want for the story completion).

All in all, it'a good game. It is not like Myst, Quern, or Talos, and instead is much more chill.

5.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 avril 2021
This game is very impressive. The graphics and audio are great. The environment is very well designed and immersive. There is pleasant music throughout the game. The puzzles are pretty good, creative with very little hand holding, and the hint system doesn't give away answers. I've spent some time scratching my head but never to the point I wanted to give up. The story seems pretty light, it has a mystery story element, but doesn't give a lot of problems to solve.

The movement is pretty slow with a lot of walking around. The environment design and music make it fairly enjoyable when exploring or going back and forth. The mouse sensitivity seems to be a problem. I set it to maximum and still have to swing my mouse around to look around. The jumping seems to be unnecessary, I don't remember any point where I needed it, but I do enjoy jumping constantly in every game.

This game clearly had a lot of time and dedication put into it. It's roughly above average for a walking sim, and pretty impressive for a puzzle game. Very polished as well. The kind of game that leaves you wanting more.

10.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 mai 2019
This is a nice exploration/puzzle game that tells the story of a girl searching for her sister in the woods. Probably the first quarter of the game is all forest/garden stuff and then you end up on an old estate for the rest. I enjoyed it but toward the end it dragged a bit.

Pros:
- nice graphics, I mean just really gorgeous
- cool concept
- music is very calming
- some nice opportunities to find hidden puzzles
- so many hidden rooms, secrets
- the main level puzzles are innovative but don't feel too difficult, are fun to work through
- not a whole lot of bugs; I can't really remember any big ones offhand

♥♥♥♥:
- VERY LONG, usually this is a plus for me but I felt the end dragged on
- not a lot of puzzle variation in the hidden puzzles, most of them are either musical memory or the one where you flip a tile and everything around it flips (I hate these things and I have no shame in telling you all that I looked up every single solution online)
- the story is confusing, there are like 3-4 (?) ghosts involved and I never really understood what even was the point...by the time you get to the estate your character like, forgets she's looking for her sister? IDK I would have liked a lot more clarity here
- a lot of lighting lamps and candles, it's a good way to keep track of where you've been in the map but it got to be really tedious after a while

Verdict:
I recommend this game for adventure/walking simulator people, anybody who likes casually wandering through scenery. The graphics are really incredible, I can't stress that enough. It's just such a beautiful, haunting setting, which is right up my alley. There is some nice creep factor to the game too, as you're wandering alone and it's mostly dark. I was very willing to forgive the story problems because the atmosphere was so on point.
