Lake Ridden sets you in a forest to find your daughter. (Who for some reason keeps running from you when she's scared)
Your mission is to solve puzzels to find out why your daughter is acting so suspicious. While you're in this supernatural forest, you find yourself solving weird puzzles to get to know your enviroment and to set yourself in world.

Pros:

1. Graphics for the game are amazing and have a perfect feel for the world.
2. Sound effects for Lake Ridden make the perfect setting when exploring the world.
3. Even though I haven't gone to much into the story; Ridden drops you in the world fast and gets you in the works of puzzels and breaks you into moving fast to.

♥♥♥♥:

1. There were a few sound bugs and movment areas in some pathways while progressing through the forest.

At the end of my review for Lake Ridden, there wasn't many ♥♥♥♥ for the game other then a few bugs for the game when it was first sent out. I can say at some points in the game you'll find yourself solving a few "Hardcore" puzzles.

At the end of the day, if you're a fan of Indie games that look and sound good and know your away around a few puzzles; This is the game for you.

However, along with the long gameplay there are problems. Puzzles begin to repeat, some of them don't have a direct logical solution, you have to use hints.

Évaluation publiée le 27 septembre 2022
Lake Ridden was a pretty narrative and traversal heavy narrative-puzzle-adventure. I had to move while playing through it, so my play-through was interrupted. Keep that in mind for my review.

The best part of this game was the system of notes, hints, and objectives. I was able to put the game down for 2 months, pick it up and figure out exactly what I need to do. I cannot recommend this highly enough for all puzzle-narrative games. Hints were there if you wanted them, but you have to deliberately open a menu for them, so they are not "top of mind". This is great because you don't think about them until you get stuck.

The puzzles were alright, most of them seemed fairly simple overall. This led to me either getting it quickly, or not at all. Puzzles were fairly well integrated into the environments, which is a touch I always like. There were some that totally came out of left field, but that felt like a state of mind problem for me, not design failures.

The Narrative was nice. Not so complex you needed to take notes to remember who people were, but still engaging enough to drive you forward and keep you wanting to progress. Solid overall.

My least favorite parts were the overall visuals, and traversal. Some of the areas are quite dark, and I found that this was on balance a negative for me. While it did add to the tone and environment, most of the time I had trouble figuring out what I could interact with, and where to go. There was also a LOT of traversal that didn't add anything for me. This is probably because I didn't enjoy the dim environments. I could see that I liked the scenery more, walking through it so much would not be as much of a problem.

Overall I liked the game, but with the mentioned reservations.

Évaluation publiée le 27 mars 2022
I had a lot of fun with this - I must say that I forgot that I had a dang map, so I spent a *lot* of time wandering around, which could have been avoided - but the setting is quite lovely during the day (when sunny and clear), and it's a gorgeous, moody place at night (when gloomy and fog-bound), so I'm not complaining. The buildings were well rendered even though drawer and closet contents were mostly identical unless something obviously important was inside.

I wasn't surprised in the story when we learn that a structure in the compound had burned down -- lighting loose candles and lanterns everywhere I went made me think I'd be burning something down, myself... But lighting everything along my way was a good way to know where I'd already been.

The mechanics were good, in my opinion. I used WASD/keyboard and my mouse and had little difficulty. Sometimes the "running" wasn't very fast - but it was when I was crouched, so it makes sense realistically. I liked that the letters/journals etc. were all saved in the inventory, and it was helpful that specific objectives were outlined under a tab in the notebook.

I did find it weird and jarring that after a puzzle box was solved, the voice-over narration had the tone of a grown-up praising kindergartners for reciting their abc's ("Congratulations for solving the ... puzzle box, kids!") Maybe that was in character with the narrator and consistent with some nuance to the character I didn't catch onto, but it felt bizarre. That said, the puzzles weren't super easy at all. They varied in difficulty, whether figuring out solutions in the game-play to keep the story moving or solving specific puzzles. Some puzzles were pretty tough and I sought help with the hint system, but most of the time I could figure them out.

The story was good, in my opinion, if a little loose.

Anyway, I really enjoyed this game and it was a satisfying finish!

Évaluation publiée le 7 janvier 2022
Lake Ridden ist ein First-Person Adventure game, irgendwo zwischen "Myst" und "The Room". Allerdings ist die Puzzledichte wesentlich geringer. Die Puzzles, die sich aus der Umgebung ergeben, sind durch interessant. Jedoch kommt das Spiel nicht ohne die klassischen Verschiebe-, Memory- oder Kombinationsrätsel aus, die sich auch noch wiederholen, worauf ich gut hätte verzichten können. Ein Tagebuch, was alle relevanten Inhalte speichert, und ein Hint-System helfen manchmal.

In der Geschichte geht es um ein altes Anwesen auf dem die Schwester der Protagonistin verschwunden scheint, Schnell wird klar, dass hier übernatürliche Kräfte am Werk sind. Obwohl hier es um eine Geschichte mit Geistern geht, enthält das Spiel keinerlei Grusel- oder Schockmomente. Alle Rollen sind jedoch aus dem Off gesprochen, was es etwas schwierig macht der Geschichte zu folgen. Am Ende ist der Plot jedoch kohärent und ich sich abgeschlossen. Man sollte jedoch keine Mind-Blowing Twists erwarten.

Die Umgebungen wirken zweckmäßig, jedoch nicht hässlich. Hier merkt man das Indie-Budget jedoch am meisten. Erschwert wird das Erkunden allerdings dadurch, dass viele Gegenstände interaktiv wirken, die jedoch nicht sind. Zumal in der Spieltwelt etliche Schränke herum stehen, die man zwar öffnen kann, die jedoch nichts Relevantes enthalten. Hier wäre eine etwas klarere Designsprache hilfreich gewesen.
Auch etwas hinderlich sind die matschigen Kontraste der Umgebungen. Gerade die Außenbereiche versinken in blassen Braun- und Grüntönen.

Der Sound enthält schöne Melodien, die sich nicht aufdrängen. Soundeffekte und Klangwelt rangiert eher auf dem Niveau "ganz okay, aber nicht herausragend".

Unter dem Strich ist Lake Ridden aber ein solides Spiel für Freunde des Genres. Eine Spielzeit von ca. 7 Stunden und einem Preis zum Zeitpunkt des Kaufes von 8€ ist durchaus fair. Mit den richtigen Erwartungen bekommt man gute Unterhaltung.

Évaluation publiée le 7 décembre 2021
“Lake Ridden” (“Lago Montado”), del 10 de Mayo del 2018, es una historia de misterio detectivesco, NO un Walking Simulator, o un Survival Horror…
Somos Marie, una niña de 13 años en busca de nuestra hermana menor, que tras una discusión se separa de nosotros. Está ambientada en 1988, en un bosque de Maine, y dentro de este (sin viaje rápido), una antigua finca olvidada, una mansión, una escuela, un barrio de servicio, un muelle y por supuesto el lago. Para resolver el misterio y finalmente encontrar a nuestra hermana, debemos encontrar pistas, resolver acertijos complicados y comunicarnos ♥♥♥ antiguos residentes. Descubriremos secretos enterrados, y un antiguo conflicto impulsado por una profunda envidia.
Como siempre la historia se completa ♥♥♥ la recolección de información esparcida en toda el área, de Trozos de Papel, Diarios, Notas, cartas, o cajas de música.
La duración es extensa, entre ocho y doce horas, si es que te gusta revisar todo. Yo no lo pude terminar, porque hay puzles complejos, empeorados ♥♥♥ un ambiente nocturno obscuro (aun ♥♥♥ corrección gamma a tope)

Évaluation publiée le 26 juillet 2021
Candles: *exist*
The Devs: BURN 'EM ALL!!!!!

This game came up as a big surprise out of a little bundle and I really enjoyed it. It's a walking sim with a spooky ghost story where you hunt for clues, solve small contraptions, unlock puzzle boxes and collect bits of the story in the form of letters and photos. Nothing stressful and that made it a plus.
It has lovely visuals, from dark to colorful and some well set spooky/mystical ambients. A big mention goes to the brilliant voice acting and the environmental sounds. Controls are just fine.

Just so you know, despite it constantly shows the saving icon, by reloading the game you'll start from the beginning of the chapter. Sometimes it's been hard to figure out where a chapter started/ended.

17.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 janvier 2022
Short review: Lots of stumbling about in the dark and fog. You can light every lamp and open every drawer which is fun until it isn't. Some really great puzzles! And a mostly helpful 'hint' system. Some annoyingly repetitive puzzles. And a spooky story which is never quite fully explained.
All in all, quite enjoyable! ^-^

Some can play it in 10-12 hours, it took me 15. Mostly wandering around trying to find 'the master bedroom' (which was earlier called the 'master study'), 'the wooden gate by the trees' (it looks like part of the fence) and the 'burned out building' which was actually the laundry. You're welcome. ;)

---

First, graphics - gorgeous. I am a big fan of first person puzzle games, I love the feeling of being there. However, the first third was at night, and stumbling around the woods in the dark is tedious. The middle third was the day, kinda? Dusk? a kind of hazy gold. And the last third is evening in the fog. Which makes it a little difficult to admire the surroundings. However, As you get close to an object, building, or puzzle, it is rendered beautifully so you feel immersed in the game.

Gameplay - I only experienced a little stutter when I came across an auto-save spot, otherwise it was pretty smooth, though the mouse sensitivity at times made the puzzles difficult to click on individual buttons or manipulate dials. There is no user Save feature, so you are at the mercy of the game. Have to leave? Be prepared to redo a few things.
I have to give credit to the game devs, the Estate is magnificently designed, with 3+ floors of rooms and a courtyard of adjacent buildings, all filled with what you could realistically expect in a place so huge. Boiler, laundry, bedrooms, book cases, desks, distillery. You can light every lamp and open every cupboard and drawer which seems cool, until you open about a thousand. Unfortunately most contain junk and a teeny percentage contain critical clues. If I never have to open another drawer it will be too soon. Lamp lighting is slightly more useful, as it can help you keep track of places you have been and find your way in the gloom. I'm sure there's an achievement for lighting all the lamps, I just got bored of it.

Puzzles - there was quite a variety of puzzles! I am a massive puzzle gamer and I have played oodles, good and bad. I would say this is middling. Earlier in the game the puzzles were more intuitive, and I only had to consult the 'hint' system for one in order to figure out the goal of the puzzle which was unclear. Later, they become more cryptic to the point I had to google a walkthrough because the hint system was like 'look closer' which was unhelpful. Still, the hints were good for the most part, nudging you toward figuring out the solution yourself.
That said, there are some very very repetitive puzzles. The puzzle boxes. By the time I reached the end I wanted to strangle the game devs. A few less would have been fine, and the reward doesn't seem to match the frustration involved.

Music - the music is calm and peaceful, except when it isn't, which sets a mood. Though there is one segment with creepy children humming as bgm and I had to turn down my speakers because it weirded me out.

Story - This I'm a little torn. You play as Marie who is searching for her sister Sofia who has gone missing in the middle of the night when camping. Marie simultaneously is in the present, yet seems to be telling the story in the future ('You may wonder why I did this, at the time I was desperate to find my sister'). Then you stumble upon an estate owned by an eccentric scientist and discover that some spooky things happened back... when? The place is abandoned, in shambles. Notes are scattered about with no signatures. This happened/are happening, with no context. And the people you 'meet' are ghosts who are invisible or don't even talk to you directly. You meet a little girl (?) and a person who I thought was a girl but is actually a young woman, who may have also been psychic? That part is never explained. As is the ending. It's not an unsatisfying ending, and it does... kinda... explain what's been happening. But it leaves as many questions as answers.

The unique puzzles were engaging, the story kept me curious, the graphics were immersive, and the spooky atmosphere was intriguing. If you don't mind the repetitive puzzle boxes (which slowly grow in complexity), and wandering around in the dark/fog, then you will surely count this as a highly enjoyable puzzle game.

Évaluation publiée le 25 aout 2021
I'm torn on this game. It was generally fine. The puzzles were moderately challenging, though most of them simply required looking around for clues to how to solve them, and then maybe a step or two of extra logic. But they were decent puzzles. The story was not my favorite. I don't love stories about ghosts, unless they are done really well (like Everybody's Gone to the Rapture).

But all that aside, I would probably have recommended the game if it weren't for the technical issues.

It started with the inability to turn off the subtitles. I find them immensely distracting when there is voiceover that is perfectly understandable. I don't want to read and listen at the same time. I'm fine with having them on by default, but please let me turn them off.

Then the game couldn't decide whether to run smoothly or be very jittery. The same settings would often go back and forth between smooth gameplay and dropping frames.

The helper text on screen was less than helpful much of the time, as it was usually telling me the buttons to press on a controller that I wasn't using, since I was using my keyboard and mouse.

Once or twice I ended up getting stuck in the terrain and no way to get out. This was extra frustrating as the game auto-saved at points that often meant I had to undo a lot of gameplay in order to get going again.

And then the game trapped me in the laundry with no way out after confronting Pearl. The first time through, I was able to follow Pearn and exit the laundry fine, then I quit the game after a short conversation. When I started again, it put me down in the laundry again, and when I tried to get out, it kept slamming and locking the door in my face before I could get out of the building. Nothing I did could fix this. So I had to choose to either quit (which I was tempted to do), replay the chapter (no thanks), or skip to the next chapter, which is what I did. I have no idea how much I missed by doing that, but it was the only way I could keep playing. Not sure whether it was worth continuing at that point or not, but I finished the game.

Overall, fine. But not memorable, and I won't recommend due to the technical problems.

Intriguing puzzle game with mild horror elements (jump scares here and there, nothing too scary). The puzzles can be frustrating, but are highly logical when you finally got it or google the tutorials like an ape like me with 2 working brain cells. The ending wasn't really quite what I was expecting and the gameplay is not too long. The game has not, however, re-playability if you manage to find all the achievements in the first run, which is very possible as the game doesn't streamline your movement too much.

There is also minor bugs where:
- When you light up a candle and move at the same time you may pounce to the direction you where moving or either back away from the object (doesn't really break the game but I definitely think it's not a feature)
- There can be places where you have yourself pushed object/s away from your path, and if you backtrack to the previous areas, the object/s might have respawned to the place they first were in your way and are IMPOSSIBLE to move. Luckily, this is fixed by just reloading your game by going to the menu and going back to the game.

Keep in mind that the game autosaves, so if you go to a new area and gather stuff or get stuck like I stated above, but don't see a saving icon when you close the game, you might need to gather them again when you relaunch the game, but the saving frequency is quite often, so you don't lose more than maximum of 5 minutes of searching.

Beautiful, atmospheric puzzle game. The exploration is great. The game lets you interact with unimportant things, like drawers with nothing in them, which makes you feel much more like you're really searching and exploring instead of just clicking around until you hit an interactive item. There's a great sense of space, and an intriguing story. The lighting is great and the environments are lovely in an eerie way. The puzzles are mostly pretty good, although the puzzle boxes (which are optional for achievements) definitely got obnoxious toward the end. The hint system is nice, since you don't have to bang your head against a wall or resort to looking up guides if you get stuck. Overall this felt extremely nicely designed and was a good experience. If you want to explore a mildly haunted mansion and solve puzzles, this game is second only to Eyes of Ara in that regard, so when you're done with that, play this.

5.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 septembre 2020
Children have been going missing, including your sister, in the woods of Lake Ridden. Finding her will entail walking through misty moonlit woods, searching sunken gardens, exploring a lonely estate, and touring a dilapidated village. Explore and discover items left behind to work out what happened and find your sister. Is it real? Is it a dream? Find your way to the exciting conclusion of Lake Ridden.

The puzzles are the main part of the game. There are a handful of puzzles that are used throughout the story of Lake Ridden which range from logic puzzles, rotating locks, “lights out” style brainteasers, pattern memory, and puzzles that require looking for clues in the general area. The puzzles are physical objects in the game and completing them advances the story—which makes the puzzles important and not seem like an afterthought. There is a good hint system in the game, along with in game notes from pertinent documents you may have found, which make the puzzles solvable. Not all puzzles were easy, but not all of them were difficult either.

The story is particularly good with only a couple of issues. The tale is narrated by the protagonist alongside other characters met along the way. Sometimes it was difficult to distinguish the different speakers or piece together who authored the various found documents which help tell the story—miss a document or some clue and you have no idea what is going on. Not knowing the overall story can make the already confusing ending that much worse. There was some discussion on Steam regarding the ending which was vague and even the creators of Lake Ridden agreed that it was left open and wanted to know peoples take on the story. I would have preferred a solid ending and better storytelling devices, but in all reality the vagueness did not really affect the game too much.

The sound was well done; the music was mesmerizing and enjoyable and the ambient sounds made the world of Lake Ridden feel lived in. The narration was okay, not the best, but it worked well with the story.

Achievements are not necessarily easy to get (which I was pleased to discover) with about half of the achievements being story based and the other half tied to finding collectibles. If you missed some achievements on the first playthrough you can use the chapter select to jump around the game to find the last of your missing achievements.

Overall, I found Lake Ridden enjoyable. Even though the ending left me a bit confused I found the story and puzzles well done and engaging. This is a good game for people who like puzzles and want to be challenged and I recommend it for them or those who like a beautiful game with a mystery to explore.

Overall an enjoyable game, though like I've seen some people say, the start was better than the end.

I like psychological and suspenseful horror, and 2/3 of the game had a really good atmosphere that made me feel like anything could happen. It was really creepy and fun to explore the area and try to guess what happened. But at the same time the plot itself felt a little disconnected and I wasn't too invested in it, and when things started going down, I felt the horror feel reduced a lot. The ending felt quite flat and I disliked how a lot of the ending was just running back and forth between places doing little tasks.

The puzzles were alright, nothing groundbreaking but some were really fun and I enjoyed the mechanics. My favorite part was the horror feel that was exactly the type I like, though again, it didn't carry to the end of the game. Still, I think it was enjoyable and if I had to get amnesia and decide if I'd play it again, I would.

On the technical side, I forgive a lot when it comes to indie games and there was nothing too bad, just that moving around was a bit cumbersome at times, the autosave didn't work perfectly, and there was some clunkiness.

If you like atmospheric horror and puzzles, I think you would enjoy this. Wouldn't exactly play it for the plot, though it was ok and worked with the horror/suspense.

11.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 septembre 2019
Although dotted with a couple of tolerable flaws, this is a fine, relaxing game in the walking-sim/mystery genre. The developers say it's not a walking sim, but we thought it was and why not? They also say it's not a horror game. We agree on that point, but it is a bit spooky here and there. Just the right amount when you want chills, but not blood. It's slightly akin to "Gone Home," in that regard.

The trailer is an accurate sample of what game-play is like, so if you like the kind of game you recognize in that trailer, you'll like this one. Negative comments have been that it has no manual save, and that you do a lot of walking long distances. We'll add that you open a lot of empty containers and that some of the puzzles are a bit repetitive. But the overall story and environment are pretty entertaining.

The absence of a manual save means you have to live with the last checkpoint the game chose to save at when you restart. You only get a moment's notice with a diskette icon in the upper right corner when it saves, and this made it a bit tricky because a similar icon in almost the same place indicates a scene is loading. You can confuse one for the other. (Also, how much longer are we going to use a diskette for an icon? You can hardly even buy them anymore.) We coped with that by running long distances which seemed to force a save, eventually. Yes, it was a bit annoying, but nowhere near enough of a problem to make us stop playing.

As for having to run back and forth to solve puzzles, we didn't mind that. Now, we are not believers in the "that's how it would be in real life" defense of a boring element in a sim. Games should be fun. If real life were as fun as games, we wouldn't need games. However, in this case, the amount of retracing our steps required actually did feel like it added to the realism of the experience, and did so without being tedious. So we actually didn't see this as a negative.

We did think the almost always empty containers got a bit dull but, again, not enough to ruin the game. The mystery unravels at a good pace, the environment is rich and interesting, and the soundtrack (music and acting) were very good. We think this one is a fine entry in the genre (whichever one or ones it's in). If you like "Eyes of Ara," "Quern," "Xing," "Myha," or "Mind Path to Thalamus," this is for you.

9.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 mai 2019
Another great walking/puzzle/mystery/adventure with one of my new favorite features: a compact world. Growing up with games like Myst and their huge worlds and sub-worlds, I find the compactness in Lake Ridden a real treat. There are just as many things to do and see, but every location is under a minute away. No HUGE back-tracking to a different world-level to complete a new step once a new piece of the puzzle is found. Here, it's as simple as "Oh, I gotta go back to that building over there."

Not that there's anything wrong with huge exploratory games like the Mysts, Obduction, Aporia, Solus Project, Firewatch, etc. ... but when I step away from those great games for a week or two, regaining my bearings upon return takes some time. If this concentrated level format is of interest to you, I also recommend The Eyes Of Ara and Quern.

Other notes:

Puzzles - There are some really great ones which required exploring, noticing the environment, and figuring out just what the heck to do. VERY impressed with these! There are also more than a few which are of similar type and difficulty to the puzzles you find in Hidden Object Games (not the hidden object scenes), but slightly harder/better.

Graphics - Top notch. If you have current hardware, you get to see some beautiful environments.

Audio - Sweeeeeet. If you collect game soundtracks, this one will make a good addition to your library.

Évaluation publiée le 3 mai 2019
This is... fine. A little spooky, remarkably pretty, especially the night sequences, but there really isn't much else to say about it. The 'mystery' is both fairly obvious and... never actually laid out, as in I had figured out the basic shape of the thing about four clues in, but why any of it happened, or mattered, or what the dude had do do with it, never came up, and frankly at that point I also didn't really care. The puzzles are more obtuse than tricky; most of it is 'find thing, take thing to several locations spread out over the map, return to first location, repeat', with some pattern matching for flavor, also not terribly complex. (If you know anything about actual mechanics prepare to be confused; I had more trouble with the 'fix the machine' sequences than anything else, mostly because, as a mechanic, the actual way you'd fix x or y was not what the game wanted you to do.)
The voice acting is very bad, but not unlistenable, the writing mostly good, but never great, and occasionally flat out boring, it's very pretty but never quite beautiful, but overall it's very much the sum of its parts, and frankly as a walking simulator mystery, it does pretty much everything it promises, so I'm not going to not recommend it. I certainly wouldn't pay $20 for it though.
tl;dr It's exactly what it says on the tin, 7/10 wouldn't play it again don't regret having done so, wait for it to go on sale.
 
Andrea Harper

Évaluation publiée le 25 décembre 2018
Στα [+]
• Δέν είναι "Τρόμου" καί δέν είναι "Walking Simulator" όπως χαρακτηρίζεται από διάφορους εδώ κι εκεί.
• Πρώτου προσώπου, μέ λεπτομερειακά διαμορφωμένους χώρους, χωρίς ευθύγραμμη εξέλιξη καί μέ άνετη κίνηση σέ μιά μεγάλη ακτίνα δράσης.
• Χωρίς τόν οποιονδήποτε σχολιασμό εκ μέρους τής ηρωίδας.

Στα [-]
• Πέρα από ένα μικρό σχετικά διάστημα, όλο τό υπόλοιπο παιχνίδι χαρακτηρίζεται από κουραστικά μαύρα σκοτάδια στό εσωτερικό τών σπιτιών κι εκνευριστικά έντονη ομίχλη στόν εξωτερικό περίγυρο. Η εξερεύνηση τών χώρων μέσα σ' ένα τέτοιο περιβάλλον δέν είναι κι ό,τι καλύτερο.
• Η εξήγηση γιά τό τόσο σκοτάδι δίνεται μέσα από τόν ρόλο τού καντηλανάφτη πού σού αναθέτει ο σχεδιασμός τού παιχνιδιού! Δεκάδες κεριά καί λάμπες σέ περιμένουν παρατεταγμένα γιά νά τ' ανάψεις προκειμένου νά φωτιστούν λιγάκι οι χώροι... Καί μπορεί μέν τό θέαμα νά είναι αρκετά όμορφο, αλλά 1) η συνεχής επανάληψή του μετά τήν πρωτοεμφάνιση στό Dear Esther αρχίζει νά γίνεται βαρετή καί 2) δέν προσφέρεται γιά τόσο μεγάλη χρονική διάρκεια καί μάλιστα σ' ένα παιχνίδι πού είσαι υποχρεωμένος νά εξερευνείς τό κάθε τί πού βρίσκεται γύρω σου.
• Η ιστορία κυμαίνεται από τό "χαζή" μέχρι τό "παντελώς ηλίθια"! Υποτίθεται ότι ψάχνεις νά βρείς τήν αδερφή σου πού έχει χαθεί μέσα στό δάσος, αλλά τελικά ασχολείσαι μέ τίς υποθέσεις κάποιων αόρατων ψυχών πού κυκλοφορούν γύρω από ένα ακατοίκητο παλιό αρχοντικό, καί μάλιστα μ' έναν τέτοιο τρόπο πού δέν μπορείς νά καταλάβεις τό παραμικρό...
• Οι γρίφοι του είναι λίγοι σέ σχέση μέ τούς χώρους καί τήν έκταση τού παιχνιδιού, καί μ' εξαίρεση 2-3 πού είναι πραγματικά καλοί, οι υπόλοιποι είτε ανήκουν στήν κατηγορία τών γιά χιλιοστή φορά επαναλαμβανόμενων, είτε αποτελούν παράδειγμα πρός αποφυγή! (Κι η εξήγηση γιά τήν τόσο μεγάλη διαφορά στήν ποιότητά τους δίνεται στά credits, όπου ανακαλύπτεις ότι γιά τήν διαμόρφωσή τους έχουν ασχοληθεί τρείς διαφορετικοί άνθρωποι).
• Μερικά τεχνικά προβλήματα πού διακόπτουν κατά καιρούς τήν κανονική ροή τού παιχνιδιού, μέ αποκορύφωμα τήν αδυναμία, σ' ένα συγκεκριμένο σημείο, νά επαναφέρεις τό ένα καί μοναδικό save! (Μετά τήν επισήμανσή του οι κατασκευαστές προχώρησαν στό άνοιγμα τών 10 διαφορετικών Κεφαλαίων πού απαρτίζουν τήν ιστορία, ξεχνώντας όμως ότι μέ τήν μεταπήδηση αυτή ο παίχτης θά χάσει όλα τά έγγραφα καί τίς σημειώσεις πού είχε μαζέψει πιό πρίν).

Συνοψίζοντας
• Καλή η προσπάθεια, αλλά δέν αρκεί. Τό Lake Ridden πάσχει κι αυτό από τήν έλλειψη ολοκληρωμένων ιδεών κι απλά τσαλαβουτάει χωρίς επιτυχία σέ ανοιγμένα πρό πολλού μονοπάτια, μιά κατάσταση πού τείνει νά γίνει κανόνας στίς σύγχρονες κυκλοφορίες.

Βαθμολογία: 1,5-2/5

http://adventures-index10.blogspot.com/2016/10/lake-ridden.html

Évaluation publiée le 31 décembre 2018
Amazing game!

The puzzles were great. There were puzzles with several "levels" to them, intuitive and incredibly fun! I did not solve every single puzzle by myself but after seeing the solution to the one or two I cheated through it should have been possible to have solved those as well. I think they are suitable for most people even though some are easier and some harder.

The story was also very good. It was interesting all the way through and it made me want to speed through some puzzles just to get to hear the rest. I liked that there was voice acting as well as the notes and journals found. The sounds, music and visuals created an awesome setting and feeling.

Somehow the game managed to create a beatiful yet a bit creepy atmosphere.

The only downside was that the mouse had acceleration (which I usually disable) and seemed to have a bug where the mouse speed changed a bit when crouching or just in specific places in the world. It was very minor.

10/10

Lake Ridden ist ein Spiel, an welches ich zuerst kaum erwartungen hatte, außer, dass die Grafik sehr schön ist. Alles in allem kann ich dieses Spiel wirklich nur weiterempfehlen!

Évaluation publiée le 30 juillet 2018
Well, ten hours played and finished. A beautiful game, no idea what the story was, didnt really care. The puzzles were good, the progression through the environments which were beautifully drawn was good. The ghost stories added some mystery and some of the letters added humour, eccentric man takes kids from the village because he thinks kids would make his home noisier and they would enjoy it there, not realising that people wouldn't take kindly to someone taking their kids...dotty old fool.

Walking simulator...puzzle game...mystery...horror...It doesnt really fit any of these labels but has bits of all of them. Small Indie dev team have made such a good job here.

Flaws, well what game has none of those, some snagging of the camera at times where it whizzes around until it settles a second later, not game breaking, not even an irritation, just an observable phenomenom.

Really interesting game that excelled in sight and sound and for ten hours I thought it excellent value for money.

Évaluation publiée le 2 juillet 2018
I was thrilled when I realised I would need to make the pen and paper scratchings of a mad person to solve these puzzles.
The game is unnerving and mysterious. It contains the brilliance of old adventure games and won't pull its punches when it comes to puzzle solving. The story is linier and the perfect length, if you trust in the game design you won't get lost. All the puzzles feel individually engaging and many have that perfect ' ah ha' moment that make you feel like you're a genius. The story is tricky so pay attention, you are very much a detective!
The game made me think of Myst and, Riven, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, Gone home, Firewatch and The Room series. The mood is tense, the world is beautiful and it plays faster than your average 'walk em up' adventure game.

Thank you Midnight Hub, I hope we see more games in this genre from you. Your designer is very clever.

I give this game a moderate recommendation for fans of the walking-sim genre, although waiting for a sale may be in your best interest.

It features a lovely and at times quite tense atmosphere through which you journey through a decently intriguing story if a bit patchwork at times, the puzzles are fairly well made although they are not always very intuitive and on numerous occasions support a number of interpretations that require guesswork or trial and error in order to filter out the correct answer. Overall a quality though struggled title that manages to stay afloat in the lake it calls home.

1.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 mai 2018
Produit reçu gratuitement

I don't have a TON of time in this game yet, but I can honestly say I'm looking forward to seeing more of it.

There's an interesting story going on in the background that sort of feels confusing... until you tie it in with the very first thing said on the intro. Those who play will know what I'm talking about there.

The puzzles aren't -too- easy, which was important to me. I don't like buzzing my way through puzzles I barely have to blink at to solve. (Well... some have been, but not the majority.) I also appreciate that they didn't put something unsolveable in there yet. Often times, in a quest to be difficult, games just -assume- you know something you really don't. Trivia knowledge, some real world history reference from a country you've never seen... any number of things.

The atmosphere is wonderful, too. It's appropriate to the game, maintains a level of 'spook' factor without seeming to guide you into a horror movie suddenly. (Maybe elements of horror themes, though. I like those.)

The list of important things:

Music, visuals and atmosphere - Great!
Storytelling - Good! (Great if you follow some of the subtleties.)
Puzzles - Great! (Sans the easy-match spinny wheel locks with lines.)
Gameplay - Good! (Clicking on an interactible to initiate a crouch is a little awkward to me.)
Overall - Amazing! Definitely worth a try if you enjoy puzzles and/or spooky stories.

Nice to have a bug free game to get lost in. I believe it is 7-9 hours long, hope it's nearer 9 for me.
